pubStmt.avail:
THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

s.w: Er, so that's it really isn't it?
Do that insurance claim of mine.

pause.w: I was thinking about getting two sets of overalls.

s.w: One in the wash, one on.

unclear.w: all that Tippex Is this Tippex?

s.w: What I've done is I've got extra extra large
and er I've asked for the er extra length one.
Cos what I thought, if I had a bigger you can always turn, you can always turn them up for us sew them and all that.
But at least I'd get the right size then.
Come on, let's have a look at you then.
Come on, let mummy wipe your face.

vocal.w: Oh you want some of this do you?

s.w: Here you are, you play with that then.

pause.w: No you can't have the whole roll.

s.w: Are you playing with the telephone?

pause.w: What do you fancy for your breakfast?

s.w: Do you want some toast and marmite?

pause.w: Peter Peter mum mum say mum mum mum mum

s.w: say mum say mum say mum Peter
We'll go and get your medicine shall we? drop of medicine?
Mummy go and get your medicine.
No no no no no no no.

unclear.c: ? You can't be doing that, no.

s.w: No, you're not gonna have it.

pause.w: You're not quite big enough yet.

s.w: No, cos you'll just throw it everywhere.

pause.w: And I'd rather you eat it than make a mess of it eh?
You can have the bowl when it's empty.

s.w: You can have the bowl when it's empty.

pause.w: Snail that goes oh so slow.

s.w: Oh you're quite enjoying this this morning aren't you?

pause.w: Decided against the toast bit of Weetabix.

s.w: Mummy hasn't had her breakfast yet.
Ooh let's wipe your nose again.

pause.w: Your mummy's got a cough too.

s.w: We're a right pair aren't we?

pause.w: Been a good boy, you've nearly eaten it all.

s.w: We're gonna have to wash your face.

pause.w: What were you doing last night in bed, eh?
Alright, we'll leave that then shall we?

s.w: Or do you want some more?
Mummy go and get your milk then.

pause.w: Are you gon na hold it?
You like mummy to hold it don't you?

s.w: I think you'd rather be playing with everything wouldn't you?

pause.w: Are you after that snail again?
You want to get up again?

s.w: Well you have to get yourself up.
You're making a mess on mummy's nice clean floor.

pause.w: You don't care though do you?

s.w: Come on then, you hold mummy's hand.

pause.w: Come on, you have to go forward.

s.w: Oh dear! hold your hands up .

vocal.w: You wan na go backwards now don't you?

pause.w: I think you are, aren't you?

vocal.w: Now what are you gonna do?

s.w: Now what are you gonna do?
You used to really like them, you did.
So you managed to get everything done?

unclear.w: was it twenty or twenty five?

s.w: I think it was just twenty wasn't it?
How much money you got left?
Have you got something to tell me?
Yeah I'll put some clean jeans on.
I've done all the dusty work.

pause.w: Looked a right state going in I tell you.
Apparently the er dust, filler dust

s.w: that er when you breathe it down right, it goes in your lungs, it doesn't shift.
It'll stay there for the rest of your life.
That's why a lot of people suffer illnesses.
Yeah, did you wear a mask?
Every now and then I never used to.
That might be one reason why I suffer a bit of asthma now.
You ain't half looking at me ain't you?

ptr.w: So what else did they have to say?

s.w: Did they ask how Peter was or not?
Yeah, they asked er how you were.
And er asked me when it was due.

pause.w: And I said er er Peter was born in Ju June and the next one's due in July the tenth.

vocal.w: You are giving me a look ain't you babe?

pause.w: Let me go and make you a cup of tea.

s.w: Do you want the fire on?

pause.w: You're not after my glasses are you?
Once upon a time there were three bears.

s.w: Mama bear, papa bear, baby bear.

pause.w: They all went for a walk down the woods.

s.w: Alright old Goldilocks she stumbled across the house.
Whoops, oh look, there's a house.
Ooh they've got some soup on the table.
So she ate all the soup
Oh you've got a little cross-eyed you are.
But like said when she tested him, she said it's erm
If it's er a proper squint are you listening?

pause.w: If it's a proper squint they don't use it.

s.w: They don't seem to use it.
You're not the one who's being chucked up in the air.

ptr.w: You'll give me a heart attack.
What's your daddy doing to you?

s.w: He was chewing his toes this morning.
You're getting a bit big to stand on daddy.
He was, he was chewing his toes.
You were chewing your toes were you?
Yeah cos he was going blah blah.

shift.w: He was screwing his face up but he was still doing it.

s.w: He thinks it's a game you see.
No you cannot have me glasses.
Well if you take them off and then they won't be out will they?

shift.w: Now he's trying to grab them .

s.w: Just be thankful you haven't got longer hair, I'm telling you.
Do you erm have we got another bill in yet?
No we've had a bill from the council.
Oh we've got a bill you see.
It doesn't say when it's supposed to be paid by so I think we might forget it for now.
Bags of rubbish from the ga there weren't no bags of rubbish in the garden.

pause.w: I think, well we'll hang on to it and then they can send us a reminder can't they?

s.w: It doesn't say anything on there.

ptr.w: That's what I was looking at.

s.w: Might get the business to pay for it.
They're tricky bastards, they really are.

unclear.w: how much was how much was there there?

s.w: I haven't you know cos it wasn't very nice when he brought it.
He was gon na stack it over this side.
But I said no, cos we don't it yet.
I said we want it behind the shed.
But whether they've actually put it behind the shed or what I don't know.

pause.w: I'd better go and have a look.

s.w: Well that's where you told me to tell him to put it, behind the shed.
I said the back of the shed.
No yeah you said the back.

pause.w: You shouldn't take him out there.

s.w: He's alright, only for a quick second.

pause.w: Is that alright, where it is?

s.w: It's pretty good wood though I think.

pause.w: I think your brother wa he was slightly worried about the amount he could take in his car.

s.w: Thought he said something about the suspension.
Gonna say I shall tell him, don't seem much there mate.

unclear.w: I could get that in my boot.

s.w: You know I just sort of
At that particular point he was whingeing away so

pause.w: That Dave's a funny old chap isn't he?
Mm, I think we're warm enough now.
Do you wan na put him in his walker?

s.w: minus your lunch if er somebody had his way.

pause.w: I won't switch the oven off just in case.
Try a bit from the middle first can you?

s.w: I'll switch the oven off then.

pause.w: Oh do you want any bread or is that alright?

s.w: Do you pick these loaves or do they feel sorry for you when they give them to you?

pause.w: I'm surprised I'm allowed to touch the loaf.

s.w: Used to have er fresh loaves all the time.
When you lived with the old man.
Well it used to last a day if that, and I never used to cut any of it.
He used to eat it all.
What a loaf of bread a day?

pause.w: Yeah he used to have a whole loaf on a Saturday.

s.w: Yeah a whole loaf he used to eat, himself.
I don't know what you've got for your dinner.
That's a point, I haven't done any I haven't got anything out.
If you want eggs you'll have to go and get some from Ann.
Yeah I know cos this morning.

pause.w: We've got ta get some eggs haven't we?

s.w: I'll pop up and get them.

pause.w: Alright, come on then bustle, let's get

s.w: Get a couple of burgers out.
You can cook them from frozen.
They won't take long to defrost.

pause.w: So are you coming straight home tonight?

s.w: I didn't know whether you might stop off at the pub or something.
didn't know whether you might stop off at the pub.

pause.w: Some people have got their washing out you know.

s.w: Some people have got their washing out.
It goes like this and then it'll cloud over and rain.

pause.w: I thought about it then I thought no, it's not worth it.

s.w: Better wait until the dries first.

vocal.w: Did that taste alright, that lasagne?

s.w: If we had a microwave it wouldn't be, would it?
We'd probably blow round the edges when I put in the freezer .
Come to think of it, yeah
Somebody there I think might like a bit of that.

pause.w: You like lasagne don't you boy?
Yeah, he's had a really good sleep actually.

s.w: He went to sleep about half eleven.

pause.w: He nearly managed to sit himself up Melvin.

s.w: He sort of pulled backwards and hit that chair, got off that chair.
And he was sort of he managed to get his legs round but he just couldn't quite get his body up to sit up.

vocal.w: So I don't think it'll be long before he 's crawling forwards.

pause.w: Dunno what I fancy for my lunch.
Didn't have my breakfast till about ten o'clock.

s.w: What's been happening on here then?

ptr.w: Oh you didn't see it did you?

pause.w: Oh erm Marie's had er a letter from her supposed parents.

s.w: And they 're at her house now.
Because they'd already warned, they've already warned her about you know sort of con people and you know
people just sort of out to get a quick buck.

pause.w: So Alright baby, do you wan na drop of milk?
No you have to wait for your lunch.
Mummy's just got a broken neck.

s.w: I think it might be the medicine he's on.
But I practically filled that this morning.
So is Robin at work today or not?
Is Robin at work today or not?
No you're not drinking mummy's tea.
You don't like my tea, it's got no sugar in it.

pause.w: Come to think of it, has daddy's got any sugar in it?

s.w: He looked like a cow chewing a piece of grass.
Here you are, give us your plate love.
Well if you have bacon now you won't be able to have it at the weekend.
Did you want mushrooms with it?

ptr.w: I mean do you want beans?

s.w: Do you want eggs with it?

pause.w: I don't know whether my brain can cope with all this.

s.w: Oh yeah we've got a good few mushrooms there.

pause.w: I feel so tired yet I've done nothing.

s.w: I went over the shop this afternoon.

ptr.w: Yeah well I wasn't gonna leave him here was I?

s.w: Bung him in the cot thing.

pause.w: No I'd never be able to forgive myself if anything happened would I?

I ain't talking cos you've got that bloody thing on.
Well, you just won't have to talk to me then will you?

Cos I'm having a job bending down.

s.w: Put them on the washing machine.

pause.w: Do you mind if I sit down and drink my tea? start tea.

s.w: Well I didn't know whether you were starving starving starving.

pause.w: No I mean he didn't want his erm milk at tea time.

s.w: He nearly weeed all over me.
He nearly got me this afternoon.
He's been watching his old man.
No, no he scraped along with his right ball.
But you can usually tell when he's going to.
You can just see at the end you know at the end, it fills like a, a little little splodge of wee.
Have you seen one of them?

pause.w: Oh god, how many's he got?
Oh no, he's gotta be joking!

s.w: I didn't realize you could still, you could buy them.
Mm I don't know where the pins are.

pause.w: Well I can give you a nappy pin.

s.w: The other thing he likes, he loves that kitchen roll.

pause.w: Have you seen him when he does it?

s.w: Keep the choke out all the time.

ptr.w: I see why you get tired sitting here.

s.w: If I sat there at night

Attached permanently by a nappy pin.

s.w: So your mum's got her wish then?
Yeah well they're going down south

unclear.w: asking, she said oh what about erm grandma?

She, she hasn't even offered any help?

pause.w: I said too interested in their own.

s.w: The only thing she offers is sort of help with Peter but that's because she wants Peter.
Not because she wants to help us.
I thought she was supposed to have him at the beginning of this month.
It depends on Diane you see.

pause.w: Well can you imagine what's gonna happen?
Don't really want him to go.

ptr.w: Well no even his mum, you know they can't cope with two.

s.w: He probably won't let Jade go cos of the dog.
Mum can have the baby and Ann can have Peter.
One has him Friday and Saturday and one has him Sunday and Monday.

ptr.w: That means they'll have to communicate.

s.w: Well communicate don't they? to talk.

pause.w: I'm not having them stuff up my plans.

s.w: It'd be easier if Sharne did.

pause.w: Why should, why shouldn't Annie and me mum?

s.w: It's different cos we wanna go away.
No Ann would have him the whole time.
Thursday night Friday night Saturday night Sunday night, four nights.

unclear.w: three in the morning or something when we get there.

s.w: I hate you and your travelling plans because they all get
Not making, I'm not making any

s.w: Well it's the best time to go.
Saves messing around with bloody road traffic.
Oh well when you're planning to go there won't be that much road traffic.
I've, I've been to Cornwall but I was so small.
Oh I remember, yeah, when you went.

vocal.w: That's why you slept in a field?

s.w: We knew it it was a long way down but .
Bloody right at the top we were.

vocal.w: He said shit, glad I never drove the car down there.
We'd have never got it back out.

pause.w: How many weeks am I now?

s.w: No it's twenty six, twenty eight is six months.
You have abortion up to twenty eight weeks don't you?
The foetus is viable at twenty six weeks.
Unless there's some medical reason, serious medical reason, they wouldn't do it.

s.w: Be so traumatic for them cos you can actually feel the baby moving

pause.w: Mm gosh, we're early this morning.

s.w: I suppose they're in my coat pocket.
You normally move your head away from me.

You'll make a mess whatever you have won't you?

You'd never think they had children of their own.

Well I'd better go wreck me car.

So if I you get forty grand now
